Comments_List: A broad overview of what the supernatural might be, but certainly what it is not, in terms of Early Modern Europe.
I learned quite a bit about the Christian tradition in early modern Europe.

This course was good for increasing my background knowledge of lived religious experience in Early Modern Europe. I also read a lot of John Calvin's writings for my essay which helped fill in a big gap in my primary source knowledge.

Professor Eire is the ultimate strength of the course. You will not meet a nicer person, who knows even half of what this man has learned in his field. Moreover, it is a fun class to take. 2 hours will go by without your having been bored once (not every time, but at least sometimes, which is an incredible testament to Professor Eire's treatment of the material and the engagement of the students in the course).

Strengths: Carlos Eire, as always. Having a mix of graduate and undergraduate students made the course very interesting. The secondary literature and its emphasis was a cool approach.

Weaknesses: Could feel unstructured at times, but overall was great.

If you have any interest in the supernatural and related concepts, this is a fun place to explore that interest. Also, just to have the time to talk with Professor Eire is a good enough reason to take this or any of his other courses.
